Fields.DialogueText: Officer Halko! Report to the main passageway, second deck at once!
Reporting as ordered, Captain. Is there a problem?
A problem? What do you think?
On the intercom, your voice sounded urgent.
Your ears are working, but try using your nose.
Use my nose? Captain, I... Oh! I can smell it now. It's...

Fields.MenuText: A bit foul, isn't it?
Completely disgusting! Any proper naval officer should be ashamed of a stench like that aboard a ship.
A sign that something is wrong.

Fields.DialogueText: Agreed. Smells like garbage, Captain.
Sorry that I didn't notice sooner, Captain, but I haven't come through this passageway since our recent combat.
It could be a ruptured pipe or header somewhere, Captain. Battle damage, maybe?
We came through that skirmish just fine. That smell isn't coming from any battle damage.
I see it now. Over here. The smell is coming from food scraps and waste water that spilled onto the bulkhead during our evasive maneuvers. Ugh.
Exactly, Officer Halko. When the crew scrambled to battle stations, they left a mess behind in the galley. Nobody bothered to clean it up when the fight was over.
Combat was the priority, Captain.
Captain?
You're right, but...
*ALARM*
Unfinished business, Halko, is still business. Get somebody to clean this up after we deal with the Morganas.
Aye aye, Captain – but let's get to our stations. I think I hear gunfire already.
@BATTLE
DISGUSTING! ABSOLUTELY DISGUSTING!
Enough shouting, First Comrade Leningrad. Officer Halko personally ensured a working detail cleaned up the mess.
I'm not talking about the MESS, Kapitan!
You aren't talking at all. You're shouting at me.

Fields.MenuText: Don't lose your temper over some spilled trash.
Don't antagonize me. I'm on our side.
LET'S SHOUT... TOGETHER! AAAAAGHHH!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not upset about the trash itself, Kapitan.
I'm not entirely certain we're talking about the same thing, Kapitan.
You look ridiculous, Kapitan... But, I now understand your point. Let's both strive to behave more professionally.
Don't forget that I'm a warship. I'm accustomed to the smells of a ship and her crew. Gun smoke, sweat, diesel fumes, bad breath, all of it.
I can tolerate a bit of spilled galley trash and a few puddles of dirty water. But a lazy crew who ignores it? THAT offends my sensibilities!
I understand, but shouting about it won't help right now.
*ALARM*
Another outlet for my hostility has arrived! Prepare to be shot full of holes by an angry Bolshevik!
@BATTLE
First Comrade Leningrad, I need an explanation for this working party outside of my stateroom.
Pleased to see it? I am. You could eat your meals off this deck when we're done with scrubbing it.
I thought my coffee cup had some soap in it this morning, but I suppose I was just smelling all of the soap out here.
Nyet, it's quite probable your coffee cup had soap in it, too. I ordered the cooks to wash everything with extra soap. I should have reminded them about rinsing.

Fields.MenuText: Ack! (spit) I should have known...
I understand your obsession with cleaning, but make sure it doesn't go too far.
Good to see some initiative and hard work, Leningrad.

Fields.DialogueText: It's better than what was in your coffee cup last week.
If people followed that advice, no revolution would ever succeed!
And yet, we still have a problem.
My concerns about the crew remain.
They're working hard. What's the concern?
They work hard because they were ordered to do it. Just like cleaning up the galley trash, they only scrub these floors because an officer told them.
Last time I checked, warship crews operate that way.
Disappointing.
Enjoy your coffee, Kapitan.
I think I'll get another cup on the bridge.
@BATTLE
What?!
Best if you forget it, Kapitan.
Do you have a moment, Kapitan? I brought coffee for you.
The door was unlocked, Leningrad.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
Your coffee. No soap in the mug this time.
Thanks. What did you want to talk to me about? We have a few minutes before the navigation brief.
Not much, Kapitan. Just one small thing. Our entire crew requires rehabilitation.

Fields.MenuText: Are you saying they need to be punished?
You're too critical. I have no issues with the crew's performance.
"Rehabilitation" sounds scary when you say it. Did you mean to say "training"?

Fields.DialogueText: Not punishment! They are not guilty of a crime, unless that crime is mediocrity.
Satisfaction with the status quo is the enemy of a good revolution!
Nyet. I meant rehabilitation, Kapitan.
The crew only commits themselves to a task when ordered. Our able-bodied women and men are capable of more!
I want them to seize opportunities! To answer a call to excellence that comes from within!
And you have a plan for how the crew will work harder, without ordering it?
I do.
And so, during the few minutes we have before the brief, I'd like to discuss my plan.
I'm all ears, First Comrade.
First, it should be noted that-
*ALARM*
Sorry, Leningrad. We've got to cut this short.
Good!
Good?
Of course! Cutting this short means no time for you to ask boring questions or say "nyet" to my plan. Spasibo!
We're not... I didn't... That's not how this works, Leningrad!
Kapitan, hurry! Battle stations!
@BATTLE
Easy to forget how steamy it gets back here in the engine room... I'll be happy to get back to the bridge for fresh air when I've finished my inspection.
A bit grimy, but everything's in working order...
*CLANK*
Step aside, comrades. Coming through!
Ah, Kapitan!
What was that clanking noise?
Probably my mop and bucket, Kapitan. I set them down when I heard you were back here.
You're swabbing the decks... In the engine room?

Fields.MenuText: You're a Belle. First Comrades don't swab the decks.
Don't you have something more important to do than mop?
If you wanted to clean up before my inspection, it's too late. I just finished.

Fields.DialogueText: Even a ship's kapitan is not above swabbing the decks!
All of my other duties are complete for the time being, Kapitan.
I'm not concerned about passing inspection, Kapitan. I'm just here to clean.
If you promise me this won't turn into a discussion about class warfare and the proletariat.
Oh, I don't think I could ever promise that...
So tell me why you're mopping in the engine room.
Just trying to show some initiative and set a good example!
All right... But, if Morganas arrive?
Always ready for that, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Next in line! Hurry up!
Oh! Kapitan! Would you like some suspicious-looking mush along with the rest of your food?

Fields.MenuText: Why are you serving everyone food, Leningrad? You have other duties besides working on the galley line!
What's supposed to be in that suspicious-looking mush?
Please tell me you didn't prepare that food yourself. And if you did, please tell me none of the officers have eaten it.

Fields.DialogueText: A Belle truly supports her people. She is never above such labor.
Nutrition. Sustenance. And zero percent capitalist extravagance.
Are you still worried that I am trying to poison people? You should trust your Belle a little bit more than that.
You didn't actually answer my question, Captain. And you're holding up the rest of the line. What will it be? Mush or no mush?
You know, you tend to get a little demanding when you're bored.
I'm going to throw this mush at you if you don't make up your mind.
Um...
Mush, please.
Spasibo! You see? That was not so hard! Nor was toiling in the galley on my free time to prepare it!
Do you see my example, comrades? Volunteering for hard work keeps our kapitan and the crew fed!
*ALARM*
What's that I hear? Oh, yes, it's the alarm. You might as well bring along that mush, Leningrad. I have a feeling it might be useful for repelling the Morganas.
Hmph!
@BATTLE
Lookout! Lookout, report all visual contacts!
Report all visual contacts, aye aye, Kapitan! I spy a clear horizon.
Leningrad?! What are you doing up there?
Hello there, Kapitan! I am standing watch as a lookout, if that was not already apparent.
We need to talk.
Have you really been meaning to speak with me? I feel so honored!
Oh, I'm sure. What did you do with the lookout?
Don't sound so suspicious. He was feeling ill, so I volunteered to take his place. I was looking for something to do, anyway.
Do the rest of you see this, comrades? Volunteering for extra lookout duty – as your First Comrade has done – helps the entire crew when one falls ill!

Fields.MenuText: You promise you weren't the one who made him ill?
That was very thoughtful of you, Leningrad.
You have been especially bored recently, haven't you?

Fields.DialogueText: How would I accomplish that, exactly? Poison his soup? Besides, you know I'd never visit harm upon our crew.
When a comrade falters, another must rise and carry the flag forward!
I'll admit, there's truth in those words. The only cure for boredom is to take action.
You now see the nature of my plan to rehabilitate the crew. I am showing them by my example to volunteer for extra work and to support each other.
Is it working?
Well...
Wait, look over there!
Morganas! Finally. I could feel my mind turning to mush up here. Come on, Kapitan!
Oh, good grief.
@BATTLE
A bit dramatic, Leningrad. It's only lookout duty.
Leningrad, if you feel the need to balance on top of the railing, I'd prefer you do it away from the other officers. I don't want them getting any ideas.
One thing I know for certain. We have no reason to fear they'll follow suit.
Or perhaps you are just jealous, since you know you don't have the equilibrium necessary to pull this off?

Fields.MenuText: You know the officers happily join in every time you act out. I can't trust them to think rationally when you're around.
Oh, yes. I'm so jealous. The envy keeps me up at night, tossing and turning. How will I ever cope?
Actually, I'm more afraid they'll try to push you over the side.

Fields.DialogueText: Amazing what a dynamic leader can inspire the masses to accomplish, isn't it?
Oh, you're so funny, aren't you, Kapitan? A regular comedian.
I would not be harmed, but I would be impressed at the attempt!
But, no matter, I'm already bored with my balancing act.
I might regret asking, but what are you going to do now?
The answer to that eludes me. My plan to inspire by example has yet to produce results.
Don't get discouraged, Leningrad. I appreciate what you're trying to accomplish.
You do? Spasibo for the kind words, but I'm not sure what good they do.
Perhaps you should try something new to break up the boredom.
I figure the Morgana northwest of us might give me something to do. To arms!
I think you mean "battle stations," Leningrad.
Whatever! Just get out of the way so I can climb down from here.
@BATTLE
Impressed?
Impressed by their revolutionary spirit to overthrow a leader, of course!
Officer Halko, I'm placing you in charge of training for our damage control teams.
Understood, Captain. You can expect to see my proposed lectures and drills in a folder on your desk by tomorrow.
Inspirational. Truly inspirational.
What? Did I miss something, First Comrade?
Forget it.
You have my apologies in advance, Kapitan. Officer Halko's training plans will be the most boring words ever placed together on paper.

Fields.MenuText: Training plans aren't supposed to be great literature.
I'll admit, I drink an extra cup of coffee before I start reading Officer Halko's paperwork.
His training plans get the job done.

Fields.DialogueText: "And never the twain shall meet."
Can you see the problem yet?
I have no doubt of that, but I see another problem, Kapitan.
Officer Halko, while perfectly reliable and functional, simply responds to the task. I wonder what goes on in that uninspired skull.
Uninspired?
Wait... That's it!
I can see those gears turning in your head, Leningrad. I'm not sure that I...
I know what we need! We need-
*ALARM*
We need to get to battle stations.
You ruin all my fun, you know that?
Blame the Morganas, not me!
@BATTLE
Any problems with the training plans, Captain?
Thoughtful and adequate. I signed off on the plans. You have my permission to implement the damage control training as soon as the schedule permits.
I'll see to it at once.
Dismissed, Officer Halko.
Finally, a moment of peace...
I have it!

Fields.MenuText: Whatever it is, you can keep it. I'm trying to relax, Leningrad.
I hope it's not contagious.
I'd ask you to contain yourself, but we both know that's impossible.

Fields.DialogueText: No time for that! You need to hear this, Kapitan.
On the contrary! That's exactly what we should hope for!
This idea will not be contained, Kapitan.
Consider this... The crew will learn how to put out a fire from Officer Halko's training. But... but how will they learn to START one?
Starting fires?
The fires of revolution, Kapitan! Of real change!
It starts when great ideas touch the mind, and those ideas come from reading books.
You're saying that if our crew read great books, they would grow?
Exactly. They would grow beyond simple training plans and boring lectures. They would grow into the autonomous, independent people that will take action!
If you want to add some literature to the crew's training, I'll need you to submit your reading list to me in advance.
HA! You want me to get your approval before I set their minds ablaze with knowledge? Hahaha! What are you AFRAID of, Kapitan? A revolution? Hahahaha!
Sigh...
Oh, let's get to battle stations, Kapitan. I sense Morganas on the way!
@BATTLE
A rare sighting of our bold First Comrade, pacing the passageways.
Hello to you, too, Leningrad. Should I ask how the crew's reading program revolution fares?
Still in progress?

Fields.MenuText: Haven't started yet, have you?
Gave up already?
Don't be rude, Leningrad. At least say hello to me.

Fields.DialogueText: I started, but now I'm stuck. If you would quit acting so smug about it, I would ask you for help.
I never give up, but I admit my progress has met with stiff resistance.
Hello, Kapitan. I meant no offense, but I've been preoccupied with a problem.
I want to expose the officers and crew to great literature, to stimulate their minds, and encourage them to grow...
And?
We lack the tools. Our ship's library is empty.
We have a ship's library?
We do now. I commandeered an empty storage closet and cleared off a few shelves.
But no books?
Exactly. We have nothing besides my own small collection. But, after much pacing, I may have a solution!
I could give a series of lectures on Bolshevik literature and ideology - from memory, of course - and the crew can just record everything I say.
Uh...
We could fill the library in no time at all!
Keep pacing, Leningrad. I might have a better idea.
Bah, Morganas are coming anyways. Just what I need!
@BATTLE
Whoa! Kapitan, where did all these books come from?!

Fields.MenuText: I've no idea, they must have materialized here, out of thin air.
Printing presses.
Books? What books? I don't see any books.

Fields.DialogueText: Goods are the products of labor. Nothing materializes out of thin air.
A wonderful invention, the printing press, placing the power of communication in the hands of the masses.
Ha. Please bring me a rivet gun to repair my splitting sides. Your attempt at humor may overwhelm my structural integrity.
I now fear that, when I called you a comedian earlier, you might have taken me seriously. I was being sarcastic.
Oh, I would have never picked up on that on my own. But, to answer your question, I bought the books for you. I placed a requisition to help out your ship's library idea.
Spasibo, Kapitan...
I expected a little more excitement, Leningrad. That look on your face tells me we have a problem.
Austen, Wilde, Carroll, Dumas, Hugo, Dickens, Twain... but these are all novels. And not even Russian novels, at that. What will this do to the crew?
You've read Pushkin and Dostoevsky. This might broaden your knowledge of the world's fiction.
Our crew have better things to do than read about an inept girl who falls down a rabbit hole into some drug-induced stupor.
And I thought you prided yourself on your open-mindedness, Leningrad. Your willingness to hear anyone's ideas and evaluate them on their own merits.
I'm not sure these even have ideas, much less merits, for that matter. Do I really want to read the sad tale of a middle-class woman unable to find an upper-class husband?
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. I think, once we're done with the Morganas, we're going to have a conversation about how to properly thank someone for a gift.
@BATTLE
Well, I see you've at least taken the books out of their boxes. How are you organizing them?
I have three piles here – one for books I've read and hated, one for books I haven't read but know I'll hate, and one for books I've never heard of.

Fields.MenuText: The pile of books you've read and hated is certainly... tall.
How could you be so sure you wouldn't like the books you've never read?
There are only three books in the third pile.

Fields.DialogueText: Not every pen should touch paper, Kapitan.
I'm confident in my assessments, Kapitan.
Honestly, I'm surprised I needed that third pile at all.
Now, I'm not saying that, just because a book is in one of these first two piles, I'm refusing to read it.
And frustration with my ship's library project could propel me into doing things I wouldn't normally. Like reading trashy novels.
I hardly think Les Misérables qualifies as a "trashy" novel.
One - Les Misérables is worse than all of the books in this room, because it's about melodramatic young people who are incapable of competently planning a revolution.
Two – there are Morganas headed this way. However, I would be thrilled, as always, to continue this debate with you after we've dealt with them properly.
@BATTLE
Leningrad, why do you look so happy? Bad things always happen when you look this happy.
So, I just finished reading a couple of the trashy novels you brought me.
What's this? Leningrad reading, and I'm going to quote you on this, "trashy novels"?
Haven't we established how lacking your sense of humor is by now?
My mind was jumbled after thinking so much about educating the crew. What better way to clear my mind, than to read something of absolutely no consequence whatsoever?
Oh, boy. Which ones?
Emma and Mansfield Park.
Oh, no.
Oh, yes. While I still think they're entirely ridiculous, I was able to learn a valuable lesson.

Fields.MenuText: There is no way this ends well.
What was I even thinking, putting a book like Emma into your hands?
I can't... I just... No... I'm leaving.

Fields.DialogueText: Contrary to your pessimism, I possess confidence in my plans.
Damn... Have I been corrupted by Jane Austen?
Wait! Listen to me!
Reading those books revealed something important about my plan to rehabilitate the crew into a more productive community.
Really?
Garbage literature could inspire the crew, if it were properly controlled. Da! That's it! Excuse me, Kapitan, but I must get to work!
As long as you promise you won't push too many boundaries...
Terrible advice for a true revolutionary. Hahaha!
Don't go too far into the rabbit hole, First Comrade. If Morganas arrive, I need you ready to fight.
I'm always ready to do battle, Kapitan!
@BATTLE
Leningrad, why are you in my office?
I only just realized I have no writing utensil. And I figured, you have a desk in your office. Desks and pens usually go together.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I trust you with a pen.
There's an old pen in the top drawer. You could use that.
Knowing you, I think you'd be happier with a pencil and eraser.

Fields.DialogueText: The world trusted a melodramatic fool like Victor Hugo with one, but my own Kapitan does not trust his Belle?
Spasibo, Kapitan.
I'll ignore that comment.
Oh... Look at this pen! It writes so smoothly! This will be perfect for my needs!
Not that one, Leningrad! It's a László Bíró ballpoint pen, one of the first produced. It's the best pen I own.
Captain! There arre Morganas headed this way!
Just, try not to break it. Or lose it. Or use up all its ink in one sitting, all right?
Your faith in me is just, really, astounding sometimes.
@BATTLE
Oh, hello, Kapitan...
From my first day reporting for duty aboard this ship, I could never expect just how terrifying it could be to hear you greet me with a smile.
So suspicious of your First Comrade! Tsk tsk.
Here it comes...
Do you have any ink refills for that pen?
My László Bíró ballpoint pen?

Fields.MenuText: The pen you stole from my desk?
I have two. You're welcome to them.
It was full when you took that pen. You emptied it already?

Fields.DialogueText: I prefer to say, "Appropriated for the cause." If it helps you to remember, though, then yes. That pen.
Spasibo, Kapitan!
I've been quite busy with that pen, Kapitan. I promise I've been using it judiciously.
After reading Jane Austen and some of the other novels you got for me, I realized they could never go into the new ship's library.
But that's why I bought them, Leningrad. The crew should get to read them.
And they will! I just had to make a few adjustments.
Adjustments?
Hence the need for more ink.
What are you doing to those books, Leningrad? Take me to the library and show me.
Um...
I'm not only the one who bought the books and gave-
Gave? Really?!
Loaned! Loaned you my pen.
Oh.
I'm also the one in charge of this warship. Take me to the ship's library, First Comrade.
Well...
*ALARM*
Another time, Kapitan! Morganas!
@BATTLE
Welcome to the ship's library! What do you think of it?
Impressive! Hard to believe this used to be a storage closet.
Plenty of shelves and large enough for a few chairs. I can imagine people will enjoy spending time here.
Looks ready. Why haven't you opened it up to the crew yet? Do you need more furniture?
The furniture is ready – the books need some work.

Fields.MenuText: These books have been ready for years, Leningrad.
Just put them on the shelves in alphabetical order.
What are you doing to the books, Leningrad?!

Fields.DialogueText: I disagree.
Organizing the books? You're missing the point, Kapitan.
A bit of modernization.
The novels you obtained for the crew, to support the reading initiative I envisioned, could truly inspire them to better themselves.
However, they might corrupt the crew with all of that ridiculous melodrama and terrible ideas.
You decided...
So, I decided to make minor adjustments and redactions to the texts before making the books available to the crew.
Oh, no! Don't tell me...
You've... You've been using my László Bíró ballpoint pen to scratch out "objectionable" material from all of the novels?!
Nyet!
No? Whew! What a relief. For a moment I thought that-
I only used your pen on some of the books. Others were so bad that I had to rip out entire chapters.
Leningrad!
What did I do now?
*ALARM*
I'm afraid that means we have to end the tour of the ship's library for now. Let's get going!
@BATTLE
You're pacing, Leningrad. Why are you pacing?
I'm deep in thought. Walking is what I do. I don't have much else to do...
We both know why I closed down the ship's library.
Temporarily closed, at least until I have time to sort things out. Find something else to do for now.
Hence, I am deep in thought.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you practiced your knife-throwing skills while deep in thought.
I thought you sang along with jazz music playing at an excessive volume while deep in thought.
I thought you recited an oath of allegiance to the Red Army while deep in thought.

Fields.DialogueText: My knife skills have been perfected. Now I mostly pace.
Define "excessive" volume.
Sometimes I do that, sometimes I pace.
But you've made your point, Kapitan.
And if you're deep in thought, what's on your mind this time?
I was just thinking about oppressive regimes, authors in captivity, manifestos, and the like.
In that case, hang on to my pen. I'll even get you some more ink, just in case your muse strikes.
Really?
*ALARM*
That's the alarm, Leningrad. You'll have to shelve your literary plans for the time being.
@BATTLE
Forget I mentioned it.
If I hand you this cup of tea, are you sure you won't drop it?
I'm more likely to throw it, after what Leningrad just did.
Oh.
I'm sorry for saying that. I'm fine, Officer Halko, really. Our First Comrade just...
She got under your skin.
A little bit.
She's good at that. I'll take the risk and hand you the cup, Captain. Here you go.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks.
Apologies again for my outburst. I should have kept that to myself.
How are you doing, Officer Halko?

Fields.DialogueText: You're welcome, Captain. You looked like you could use it.
Don't worry about it, Captain.
Honestly, warship life is always a challenge for me. But I know that I'm not alone, so I'll be fine.
We're all on the same team, you know.
I'm shocked, but I guess I shouldn't be surprised.
Shocked? At First Comrade Leningrad's behavior?
No.
I'm confused, Captain, but I won't pry. If you need a little bit of time to relax, I can postpone the next gunnery practice.
Actually, Officer Halko, I'm suddenly feeling better than I have in a while!
*BOOM*
Sounds like gunnery practice started early...
That's not gunnery practice. Listen more carefully.
Morgana cannons! Let's get to the bridge!
@BATTLE
You're practicing your knife-throwing.
*THUNK*
Yes, I am.

Fields.MenuText: How much trouble am I in?
You're not going to throw those at me, are you?
I'm sorry about what happened with the library, Leningrad, but we didn't have much choice.

Fields.DialogueText: None, Kapitan. None. At. All. I can't say the same for that piece of fruit.
You are never my target, Kapitan.
You have no reason to apologize for your decisions, Kapitan.
I'm not mad at you, Kapitan. It was strange, because I thought I would be. I worked hard on that library, but I know you act out of concern for the crew.
That's very mature of you, Leningrad. I really appreciate that.
If we cannot accept some criticism, we will never grow.
Another mature observation.
And then, of course, reluctance to change the status quo will inevitably result in the rising of the Bolshevik masses to overthrow the source of the oppression.
Uh... That isn't exactly where I would go with the observation. Maybe this has gone a bit off track.
Nonsense, Kapitan. A revolution is precisely how society maintains its proper course!
You hear that? There are Morganas coming. Maybe I can peg them in the head with these knives.
It might help me ignore the sting of my failures.
@BATTLE
Great news, Officer Halko. I'll be sure to pass it along to Leningrad.
No need to look for her, Captain. Here she comes.
Kapitan, Officer Halko. Can I be of any assistance?
Officer Halko just reported to me that the galley passed a surprise inspection for cleanliness.
Oh? Somebody must have leaked the secret to the crew, and they cleaned up ahead of time to avoid getting punished.
I assure you, that is not the case, First Comrade. I just happened to walk by the galley, and I'd never seen it cleaner in my life.
When I told the Captain, we both decided to give the crew credit for passing a "surprise inspection" to recognize their spontaneous efforts.
Spontaneous? Nobody ordered them to do it?

Fields.MenuText: They did it themselves.
Maybe the crew isn't as lazy as you think!
Did you order the crew to clean up the galley, Leningrad?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh...
Something changed them...
Nyet. I was busy throwing knives at the seagulls all day.
Officer Halko, can I talk to Leningrad for a moment?
Of course, Captain.
You wanted the crew to grow up and take a little more initiative – not just wait for orders. Maybe it's working.
I'm confused. How did they... ?
One more thing. I've been thinking about it, and I want your ship's library open. However you want to run it, just do it.
Really?
Really.
With pleasure, Kapitan!
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
No longer shall information and literature be withheld from the proletariat's grasp!
No longer will the diversions of the upper class remain exclusive!
Why are you shouting, Leningrad? There's nobody else here.
I'm practicing. When the oppressed masses eventually storm this tiny ship's library in search of enlightenment, I want to guide them!

Fields.MenuText: Um... If an oppressed mass shows up, let me know.
Keep it up!
Bored sailors will read books, but you won't get a frenzied crowd showing up demanding to read Jane Austen.

Fields.DialogueText: I can handle spirited crowds, Kapitan! Trust me to keep the situation under control.
Spasibo! I will!
When it comes to Jane Austen... I hope you are right, Kapitan.
You seem pleased to get this library going, crowds or not.
I will be, once I have resolved another matter with you.
What matter is that, Leningrad?
I'm sorry about your László Bíró ballpoint pen. Besides using all of your ink, I also disrespected the books you thoughtfully purchased for me.
Forgiven. No need to-
Even though so many of those books were garbage.
That was a joke, Kapitan!
No hard feelings, Leningrad. Maybe work on your timing a little, though.
*ALARM*
To say nothing of Morgana timing! And on the library's opening day! How dare they!
Let's get going!
@BATTLE
Do you spend all of your off-watch time down here?
Not all of it, but this little ship's library tends to keep me busy.

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure the crew appreciates that.
Glad to see you find a hobby that doesn't involve knife throwing.
It's a storage closet with a few dozen novels on the shelves. How can this possibly keep you busy?

Fields.DialogueText: Quite a few crewmembers borrow books to read, and I don't mind making recommendations.
Ever throw knives at a copy of Mansfield Park? I can't recommend that enough!
Fine! I'll admit, it requires hardly any thought or effort at all.
So far, not a single sailor has complained about the edits I made with your ballpoint pen.
Your readers aren't too discriminating?
On the contrary! It means they have good taste. I can vouch that removing any of the words - or better yet, pages - from a Jane Austen novel improves the quality.
Not everybody would agree with you, but there's no accounting for taste, I suppose.
I came to the same conclusion!
I'll admit, this library demands little of my time, but I am waiting for something to happen. I'll let you know when, and then I'll have more spare time for other duties aboard the ship.
As long as you aren't ripping out more pages or editing the books, take all the time you need.
*ALARM*
As long as...
Don't worry, Kapitan! I always put the mission first!
@BATTLE
It happened! It happened!
Did an engine explode?
Did we sustain crippling hull damage?
Nothing of the sort, comrades! The event I was waiting for... At the ship's library... It finally happened!

Fields.MenuText: You actually got a customer to show up?
Somebody finished reading War and Peace?
You enjoyed reading Jane Austen?

Fields.DialogueText: Very funny, Kapitan. Many of our crewmembers enjoy borrowing books. I'm talking about something else...
Nyet... I have not been able to claim victory on that front. I'm talking about something else...
Have no fear, Kapitan. If that happened, I would quickly agree to a mental evaluation by the ship's doctors. I am talking about something else...
One of the crewmembers, Officer Sowa, read Les Misérables...
And her head exploded?
None of this conversation is making sense to me...
Consider yourself lucky, Officer Halko.
She hated it! I'm so proud of her!
Did she really hate it?
Well, I may have exaggerated. She said it dragged on a bit too long.
Oh.
And she read the copy where I had already torn out a dozen chapters!
I don't know what to say, Leningrad.
Congratulations, First Comrade? Again, I have no idea what is going on here.
Congratulations, indeed, Leningrad. You brought books to the masses, and they experienced something new.
Spasibo, Kapitan! I'm personally thrilled that such melodramatic nonsense did not pollute her mind. Our crew is strong enough to withstand Victor Hugo and remain functional.
And strong enough to withstand Morgana attacks, too. That's what I care about.
*ALARM*
Let's find out!
@BATTLE
Cup of coffee? The stewards made a fresh pot, so I grabbed one for you on my way here. There's no soap on the mug! I checked.
A cup of fresh coffee makes any stateroom more pleasant. Thanks, Leningrad.
Do you need to hurry back to the ship's library?
Officer Sowa volunteered to be the ship's librarian today.
Volunteered?
I was even more surprised when others volunteered to help out, too. I posted a sign-up sheet outside the door, and it was full within an hour.
Really?
The crew takes more initiative and more interest in their mutual welfare now. It's...
Not just cleaner uniforms and better food preparation, but they're faster to help out and volunteer for things. They care about each other a little more.

Fields.MenuText: It was always happening. You just didn't see it.
Your books made a difference.
You set the example for them to follow. Volunteering for help out and trying to improve their lives showed them the way.

Fields.DialogueText: But not to the same degree as now. We both remember the stink of that ignored galley mess, right?
Maybe the content of the books didn't matter much to the crew, but the fact that they had a library made an impression. Hard to say.
I hope so. I didn't exactly enjoy standing lookout watch and cooking mush!
You've got passion and a willingness to lead the charge, First Comrade Leningrad. Inspiring people comes naturally to you!
One person makes a difference, but they don't make it alone. I realized something about you, Kapitan.
Uh oh. Is this where you rally the crew to a mutiny?
Ha! You know that would never happen. You're a sharp leader, Kapitan, but you're even more than that to me.
I consider you a comrade and a true friend. I'd brave Morgana guns with you any day.
How about we enjoy this coffee first, and then we go win the war?
A revolutionary idea, comrade!
Morganas to starboard. Guns up, Leningrad!
@BATTLE
